flashcards.definition: The process of taking food into the body through the mouth. It is the first step in holozoic nutrition.
The breakdown of complex food molecules into simpler, soluble forms that can be absorbed by the body. Involves mechanical and chemical processes.
The process by which digested food passes through the intestinal wall into the bloodstream. Occurs mainly in the small intestine through villi.
The process by which absorbed food is utilized by the body for energy, growth, and repair of tissues.
The removal of undigested food material from the body as feces through the anus. Final step in holozoic nutrition.
Enzyme present in saliva that breaks down starch into maltose. Also called ptyalin. Works best at neutral pH.
Wave-like muscular contractions of the alimentary canal that push food forward through the digestive system.
Digestive juice secreted by gastric glands in the stomach. Contains HCl (hydrochloric acid), pepsin, and mucus.
Protein-digesting enzyme present in gastric juice. Works best in acidic conditions (pH 1-2) and breaks proteins into peptones.
Acid present in gastric juice that creates acidic medium for pepsin, kills harmful bacteria, and helps in protein digestion.
Finger-like projections on the inner wall of the small intestine that increase surface area for absorption of digested food.
Greenish-yellow liquid produced by the liver and stored in gall bladder. Emulsifies fats (breaks into smaller droplets) but is NOT an enzyme.
Digestive juice from pancreas containing enzymes: trypsin (for proteins), lipase (for fats), and pancreatic amylase (for starch).
Protein-digesting enzyme in pancreatic juice that breaks down proteins into amino acids. Works in alkaline medium (pH 8).
Fat-digesting enzyme present in pancreatic juice that breaks down fats into fatty acids and glycerol.
Front teeth (8 total) used for cutting and biting food. They have a chisel-shaped edge.
Pointed teeth (4 total) next to incisors used for tearing and piercing food. Well-developed in carnivores.
Back teeth (8 premolars + 12 molars) with broad surfaces used for crushing and grinding food.
The long tube extending from mouth to anus through which food passes during digestion. Also called digestive tract or gut.
The process of breaking down large fat droplets into smaller ones by bile. This increases the surface area for lipase enzyme action.
Finger-like projections of cell membrane in amoeba used for movement and capturing food. Means 'false feet'.
Process by which amoeba engulfs food particles using pseudopodia, forming a food vacuole inside the cell.
Grass-eating animals (like cow, buffalo, deer) with four-chambered stomach that can digest cellulose with help of bacteria.
First and largest chamber of a ruminant's stomach where cellulose digestion begins with help of bacteria. Food is stored here temporarily.
Partially digested food that ruminants bring back from stomach to mouth for further chewing. This process is called rumination.
Final part of digestive system where water is absorbed from undigested food and feces is formed before egestion.
